justification: The article states that the Balloon Analogue Risk Task (BART) "measures risk-taking propensity by emulating an uncertain decision context with probabilistic rewards."

measured_by: adjusted BART score (mean number of pumps for unexploded balloons)
justification: It is noted that "the adjusted score (mean number of pumps for unexploded balloons) has been repeatedly associated with real life risk-taking behaviours," indicating it is the behavioural index used to quantify risk-taking propensity.

measured_by: target number of pumps parameter (k) from the Scaled Target Learning models STL / STL-D
justification: The text explains that STL and STL-D include a parameter estimating "participants' target number of pumps," and that this parameter "showed improved external validity compared to the adjusted BART score … suggesting an improved ability to capture individual differences in risk-taking propensity."

measured_by: normalised learning rate difference (vwin – vloss) estimated with the STL-D model
justification: The Methods section states that learning bias was "quantified by normalising the learning rate difference" between vwin and vloss for each participant, indicating this computed parameter operationalises the construct.

measured_by: vwin parameter of the STL / STL-D model
justification: The modelling description specifies that STL and STL-D "implement separate learning rates for wins (vwin) and losses (vloss) to account for the distinct sensitivity to rewards and punishments," making vwin the measure of learning from positive feedback.

measured_by: vloss parameter of the STL / STL-D model
justification: In the same passage, vloss is introduced as the parameter representing the learning rate for losses, thus operationalising learning from negative feedback.
